path: /blog/Exploratory data analysis summary done on tables with 57,622 canvassing records!

contentfulPost.title: Final Data Analysis with Generation Progress

content.value: I recently finished the virtual training on progressive data management with Generation Data. In two weeks we developed practical skills used in the progressive data space including using VAN (voter management system), excel, Tableau, and GQIS.
This program ended with a project in which we analyzed sample data on a Postgres server. This server had seven tables in total.

Demographics
Geography
Modelscores
modelscores_rescores
survey_responses_passtwo
surveyresponses
votehistory
 
The goal of the project was to obtain the opportunity to use our new acquired skills to develop an exploratory data analysis on simulation campaign data.
The following is my submission, this work was done in 48 hours,  2 days.
Data Description and Statistics

To get started I first took a look at the different tables available, I identified possible relationships that could exist between the different tables. Considering the given situation and stakeholders (LCV, CWA, IBEW, PPFA), I identified the important measurable data available and possible outcomes that I could obtain from the data collected. To do this I simply did calculate descriptive statistics by using aggregate SQL functions (count, sum, group by, when) on the canvassing tables.
Initial Hypothesis and Analysis

After reviewing the canvassing tables I figured that the important information they provided included the level of support,  voter contact success, and whether they wanted to volunteer or not.  One question I wanted to explore was if there was a correlation between the date and successful canvass.  A successful contact is being able to speak to the voter (they answer support questions or volunteer questions).  For these steps, I was able to gather descriptive statistics by using aggregate SQL functions (count, sum, group by, when) on the canvassing tables.
Joining Tables

One quick look invented using the canvassing tables was graphs of the relationship between the dates that were canvassed and the results. in total 8 days or canvas between both campaigns, each of those days had similar results. My initial hypothesis was that on certain days pacifically weekends there would be higher results poor canvassing efforts.
Demographics

After tabulating descriptive statistics from the tables themselves then I looked at the Cannabis in tables joint with the demographics table. I did this because I wanted to get information about the success of our canvas in regard to age. This particular question’s response data could provide some preliminary guidance for the digital team for targeting by age. For these questions, I could have used SQL as well but decided to use tableau because this is visualization would be made available more readily.
Organizations

Considering that's a data collecting was being put together from the efforts of the four organizations participating in this table, I wanted to go ahead and break down the results by the organization. I think this would provide some insight into quality of different programs that would benefit the organizational table. We could identify a program that is high or low performing and take steps to examine the current strategy and determine improvements to bring up to success to that of others.
Mapping

Finally wanted to use the data to attempt to split canvassing efforts to identify any hot spots.  This could help us identify spots that we are not canvassing.  In addition, by plotting support levels or volunteer levels on the map, we could potentially identify hotspots for those fields.
From the current data, and from looking at the state map, no noticeable concentration spots were decipherable.
Conclusions

In conclusion through the exploration of this data and tables, I was able to start to get an understanding of metrics that can be obtained from canvassing data in campaigns. I was able to get some insight into some of the questions that I came up with initially. But more questions came to mind which required access to other data, including more dates of canvassing.
All three tools used provided different insight, had limitations, and varying levels of complexity.
On the maps, the statewide view wasn’t easy to decipher. I think county-level data plots might be more insightful, especially to field organizers.

Historical data of previous canvases, in the previous elections, would be useful. One example of additional data that could be useful in the identification of different script used, to measure the success of script (something like A/B testing).
Another data table that could be useful would be social media data, that could be connected via van ID, address, or email. I don't know if this data is available.
Future explorations include obtaining census data that provides the voting population by counties to obtain percent contacted, with respect to adult voting progressive population.
